Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Proposal Title: CAREER: Social Networks, Labor Markets and Agricultural Technology Adoption in Developing Countries
Proposal Number: SES - 1254380
Principal Investigator: Beaman, Lori A.

This CAREER seeks to provide insights into how social networks affect economic behavior in developing countries in two key domains: labor markets and agricultural technology adoption.

The starting point for the first topic -social networks and labor markets- is that a large body of evidence shows that the quantity and quality of an individual's social network influences his or her labor market outcomes. Theory suggests social networks may exist in order to address market failures such as asymmetric information. Previous work by the Principal Investigator (PI) supports that individuals have useful information about fellow network members. However, the use of social networks in hiring decisions may reinforce existing inequalities, as those with few or poor-quality network connections could be further isolated from job opportunities. Women in particular report using social networks less often and also have worse labor market outcomes on average. Using a recruitment experiment in Malawi, the project looks at whether women are disadvantaged by referrals, and if so, why?

The second area is agricultural technology adoption: An important puzzle in development economics is why farmers do not use simple and seemingly profit-enhancing technologies. While there may be numerous constraints to technology adoption, imperfect information about the technologies could be an important factor. This project asks how social networks can be harnessed to improve the dissemination of information. The research also relates to recent work in economic theory on how network structure affects the diffusion process. Several interrelated projects in this area seek to answer empirical questions, including: 1) Do individuals with more agricultural experience generate positive spillovers to their neighbors? 2) Can agricultural extension agents partner with well-connected farmers to increase technology adoption? 3) Which social network characteristics (betweenness, degree, eigenvector centrality) of seed farmers most influence diffusion of information on new agricultural technologies? 4) Does targeting well-connected farmers come at the cost of increased inequality of knowledge within rural villages? These projects all employ novel data collected to precisely answer these questions, including social network censuses of many villages in Mali and Malawi. New methodologies are also used, such as integrating theory into a field experiment by using simulation of diffusion models and baseline social network data to determine which farmers in Malawi should receive training on new technologies.

Broader Impacts: One limitation of much of the previous research on social networks is that there are few policy implications. Policymakers can rarely alter people?s social networks. An objective of this CAREER project is to find ways in which policymakers can use the deep social networks which exist in developing country contexts to improve the effectiveness of policy --in particular to increase the adoption of simple agricultural technologies which can raise incomes and reduce poverty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social networks structure human interaction and channel flows of information. This CAREER research drew on three experiments—two in Malawi and one in Mali—to explore how networks affect economic behavior in two domains that are vital to economic development: job referrals and agricultural technology adoption. While existing research demonstrates that network characteristics influence economic outcomes, it is rare that policymakers can significantly alter networks. The present studies address a major academic and policy gap by identifying how different ways of using already-existing networks can improve the spread of information.

 One important function of social networks is job referrals, which account for a large share of hiring decisions. Theoretically, it is unclear how referrals should affect the gender equitability of hiring. The first study tested the effects of alternative referral-based hiring mechanisms in the context of a recruitment drive for a firm in Malawi hiring survey interviewers. Participants referred candidates under conditions that were randomly varied across three dimensions: candidates were asked to select women, men, or either gender; were offered a fixed fee or a contract based on the referral’s performance; and were informed that performance would be measured by an absolute threshold or relative ranking.

Men systematically referred a lower proportion of women than had applied through non-referral channels, and this trend persisted regardless of the performance pay condition. But, strikingly, men were able to refer qualified women candidates when asked. On the other hand, women were roughly even across genders in their referrals, but drew from a less-qualified applicant pool. This study was published in the Journal of Labor Economics.

Like job referrals, information on agricultural technology often flows through social networks. In many agrarian settings, agencies send extension workers to train farmers on technologies. But costs prohibit training each farmer individually, so extension workers typically train “seed farmers”—farmers who they expect to teach others. The remaining two experiments test how network-informed methods of seed farmer selection lead to differing patterns of information diffusion.

Farmers may not adopt technologies because it is very difficult to convince them that the technology is appropriate. A threshold model, where a certain fraction of one’s social contacts must have previously adopted a behavior before you yourself adopt, may help explain persistently low take-up. In Malawi, investigators collaborated with the government to test whether and how information on two technologies—pit planting and crop residue management—disseminates differently if seed farmers are chosen based on the predictions of a threshold model, compared to the status quo (extension workers choosing seed farmers). A noteworthy methodological innovation of the study was to employ threshold model-based simulations to select seed farmers, i.e., to define the treatment.

Threshold-based selection increased knowledge diffusion and technology adoption most, but an inexpensive alternative also performed significantly better than the status quo. Given the expenses of collecting network data, the results thus highlight the promise of investing in methods to approximate network data.

The third experiment explores information diffusion relating to another technology—composting—in 52 villages in Mali. For this study, four seed farmers were selected in each village according to one of three randomly-assigned criteria:  highest degree (number of network contacts); highest betweenness (targeting farmers who serves as bridges linking other farmers); and random selection. Each farmer was given informational placards and instructed to distribute them to other farmers. Researchers then returned a month later to see which farmers had received placards, and to measure farmers’ knowledgeability about composting. Results show no difference in overall information spread. However, women were heavily disadvantaged by the betweenness seed selection, revealing a potential unintended consequence of targeting a network’s core: exacerbating pre-existing inequalities. This study was published in the Journal of Development Economics.

In addition to contributing to the academic fields of development, agricultural, and labor economics, this research contributes concrete policy insights. The job referral study suggests that firms should consider the potentially skewed effects of referral-based hiring when weighing the costs and benefits of alternative hiring schemes, and that following up with women candidates recommended by men can be at least as promising as relying on referrals from women. The Malawi agriculture study highlights the importance of developing ways to put network theory into practice through relatively inexpensive approximation methods. And the Mali agriculture study reveals potential equity costs of network-based information diffusion, depending on the nature of the networks and how nodes are chosen. Collectively, these experiments establish the central role that social networks play in shaping the flow of economic and information, and motivate continuing research on how network insights can be leveraged to make diffusion more equitable. The grant also helped to support a conference on “Financial Inclusion and Agriculture” held in Burkina Faso in 2016, which included a training on impact evaluation and presentations of research on agricultural development.
